nodes.text: will cover the benefits of how Go's error model results in more reliable code. We will cover how to handle basic errors and return errors as an interface that satisfies the error type. Additionally, concepts such as custom error types, panics, recovering from panics, and sentinel errors are also covered.
A lot of languages use the concept of

. When something goes wrong, an exception will be thrown. This exception then needs to be caught. When catching an exception you have the opportunity to log the exception and possibly move on with an alternate code path, or re-raise the exception and let the developer upstream deal with the problem.
shows an example of how to handle exceptions in Java.

nodes.name: example

nodes.text: Go takes a different approach and treats errors as values. These values are returned and managed instead of throwing and capturing exceptions,

nodes.name: example

nodes.text: In Go errors are represented by the
Go provides two quick ways to implement the
. This function takes a string and returns an implementation of
that uses the supplied string as the error message.

$ go doc errors.New

package errors // import "errors"

func New(text string) error
    New returns an error that formats as the given text. Each call to New
    returns a distinct error value even if the text is identical.

$ go doc errors.New

package errors // import "errors"

func New(text string) error
    New returns an error that formats as the given text. Each call to New
    returns a distinct error value even if the text is identical.
When creating errors, it is common to want to create a string that contains the error message and the values of variables that caused the error.

nodes.content: err = errors.New(fmt.Sprintf("error at %s", time.Now()))
nodes.name: new

nodes.text: To clean up the pattern seen in

$ go doc fmt.Errorf

package fmt // import "fmt"

func Errorf(format string, a ...any) error
    Errorf formats according to a format specifier and returns the string as a
    value that satisfies error.

    If the format specifier includes a %w verb with an error operand,
    the returned error will implement an Unwrap method returning the operand.
    If there is more than one %w verb, the returned error will implement an
    Unwrap method returning a []error containing all the %w operands in the
    order they appear in the arguments. It is invalid to supply the %w verb
    with an operand that does not implement the error interface. The %w verb is
    otherwise a synonym for %v.

$ go doc fmt.Errorf

package fmt // import "fmt"

func Errorf(format string, a ...any) error
    Errorf formats according to a format specifier and returns the string as a
    value that satisfies error.

    If the format specifier includes a %w verb with an error operand,
    the returned error will implement an Unwrap method returning the operand.
    If there is more than one %w verb, the returned error will implement an
    Unwrap method returning a []error containing all the %w operands in the
    order they appear in the arguments. It is invalid to supply the %w verb
    with an operand that does not implement the error interface. The %w verb is
    otherwise a synonym for %v.
the code is now cleaner and more readable than in

nodes.content: err = fmt.Errorf("error at %s", time.Now())
nodes.name: errorf

nodes.text: With errors being a type in the Go type system, in this case an
type, errors can be returned from, and accepted as, function arguments.
In Go, if an error is returned from the function, it should
be returned as the last argument. While the Go compiler won't enforce this, it is the expected idiom in the Go ecosystem.

nodes.text: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
itself has outsold the Encyclopedia Galactica because it is slightly cheaper, and because it has the words DON'T PANIC' in large, friendly letters on the cover."
Arthur C. Clarke said Douglas Adams' use of
was perhaps the best advice that could be given to humanity.
Occasionally, your code you will do something that the Go runtime does not like. For example, in
, if we try to insert a value into an array or slice that is beyond the bounds of the array or slice, the runtime will panic.

nodes.name: example

nodes.text:
$ go run .

panic: runtime error: index out of range [42] with length 0

goroutine 1 [running]:
main.main()
	./main.go:6 +0x24
exit status 2

$ go run .

panic: runtime error: index out of range [42] with length 0

goroutine 1 [running]:
main.main()
	./main.go:6 +0x24
exit status 2
A panic caused by an out of bounds index.
A panic in Go can be raised using the built-in

$ go doc builtin.panic

package builtin // import "builtin"

func panic(v any)
    The panic built-in function stops normal execution of the current goroutine.
    When a function F calls panic, normal execution of F stops immediately.
    Any functions whose execution was deferred by F are run in the usual way,
    and then F returns to its caller. To the caller G, the invocation of F then
    behaves like a call to panic, terminating G's execution and running any
    deferred functions. This continues until all functions in the executing
    goroutine have stopped, in reverse order. At that point, the program is
    terminated with a non-zero exit code. This termination sequence is called
    panicking and can be controlled by the built-in function recover.

    Starting in Go 1.21, calling panic with a nil interface value or an untyped
    nil causes a run-time error (a different panic). The GODEBUG setting
    panicnil=1 disables the run-time error.

$ go doc builtin.panic

package builtin // import "builtin"

func panic(v any)
    The panic built-in function stops normal execution of the current goroutine.
    When a function F calls panic, normal execution of F stops immediately.
    Any functions whose execution was deferred by F are run in the usual way,
    and then F returns to its caller. To the caller G, the invocation of F then
    behaves like a call to panic, terminating G's execution and running any
    deferred functions. This continues until all functions in the executing
    goroutine have stopped, in reverse order. At that point, the program is
    terminated with a non-zero exit code. This termination sequence is called
    panicking and can be controlled by the built-in function recover.

    Starting in Go 1.21, calling panic with a nil interface value or an untyped
    nil causes a run-time error (a different panic). The GODEBUG setting
    panicnil=1 disables the run-time error.
function we can recover from panics in our applications and gracefully handle them.

$ go doc builtin.recover

package builtin // import "builtin"

func recover() any
    The recover built-in function allows a program to manage behavior of
    a panicking goroutine. Executing a call to recover inside a deferred
    function (but not any function called by it) stops the panicking sequence
    by restoring normal execution and retrieves the error value passed to the
    call of panic. If recover is called outside the deferred function it will
    not stop a panicking sequence. In this case, or when the goroutine is not
    panicking, or if the argument supplied to panic was nil, recover returns
    nil. Thus the return value from recover reports whether the goroutine is
    panicking.

$ go doc builtin.recover

package builtin // import "builtin"

func recover() any
    The recover built-in function allows a program to manage behavior of
    a panicking goroutine. Executing a call to recover inside a deferred
    function (but not any function called by it) stops the panicking sequence
    by restoring normal execution and retrieves the error value passed to the
    call of panic. If recover is called outside the deferred function it will
    not stop a panicking sequence. In this case, or when the goroutine is not
    panicking, or if the argument supplied to panic was nil, recover returns
    nil. Thus the return value from recover reports whether the goroutine is
    panicking.

Now, if a user inadvertently raises a panic in the
function will handle it gracefully and return an error, instead of panicking as well.
When something panics in Go you have three options for how to handle the panic.
You can let the panic crash the application and deal with the fall out.
You can recover from the panic, log it, and move on.
You can properly capture the panicked value and return it as an error.
, gives you the most control over recovering from panics. However, it requires a number of steps, and functions, to make this happen.

Tests now pass after proper panic recovery.
NEVER RAISE A PANIC IN YOUR CODE
is too strong of a stance. However, in general, it's considered non-idiomatic to panic instead of returning an error outside of specific conditions.

When a panic occurs, unless there is a recover in place, the program will shut down (usually not gracefully). It is usually a much better practice to return an error, and let the code upstream handle the error.

The general rule is that if you are writing a package, you should not panic. The reason for this is that the caller should always have control of the program, and a package should not dictate control flow of a program.
On the other hand, if you are the caller (maybe you are in control of the
function in the program), then you already have total control of the program flow, and if needed, a panic may be appropriate. Many times this is manifested in the form of a
, which will exit the program with a non-zero exit code.

Lastly, any code that panics may be more difficult to test. For all of these reasons, it is best to consider alternatives to a panicking. After all, most panics can be prevented by sensible code and well designed tests.
The most common source of panics in Go are calls being made on
values. Any type in go that has a zero value of
can be a source of these panics. Types such as interfaces, maps, pointers, channels, and functions all fall into this category. Checking whether these types are
before using them can easily avoid these panics.

If asked, Go, will return a second argument, a boolean, during the assertion. That boolean will be
if the assertion was successful and
if it wasn't. Checking this second argument will prevent panics on type assertion failures and keep your application up and running.

expected *os.File, got *bytes.Buffer

exit status 1

expected *os.File, got *bytes.Buffer

exit status 1
Proper type assertion checking prevents panics.
Note: It is very important that a type check is not avoided. In virtually all cases, avoiding a type check will lead to a future bug in your code.
When accessing indexes on slices and arrays if the index is greater than the length of the slice/array Go will panic.

nodes.text: A function for retrieving the index of a slice.
. This function attempts to access the given index of the given slice. If the index is greater than the length of the slice, Go will panic,

To avoid this panic, check the length of slice/array to ensure the requested index can safely be retrieved. In
, the index is checked against the length of the slice/array before being accessed. If the index is greater than the length of the slice/array, the function will return an

As we have seen, errors in Go are implemented via the
. This means we can create our own custom error implementations. Custom errors allow us to manage workflow and provide detailed information about an error beyond the scope of the
. A couple of types are being defined. The first,

, it might be tempting to assert against an error's message, but that is considered non-idiomatic and should never be used. The reason for this is simple; error messages change. If the error message changes the following test will fail. We consider this to be a "brittle" test.
We can define custom errors that can help distinguish one error from another, as well as, add more context around the error.
interface. This type will contain information such as what table was missing and what time the error occurred.

A wrapped error can no longer be asserted against correctly.
In order to get to the original error we need to unwrap the errors until we reach the original error. This is similar to peeling an onion, where each error is a layer of wrapping.
Let's take a simplified look at how wrapping and unwrapping errors works in Go. Consider the
field that holds the error that is wrapping.

nodes.name: errors

nodes.text: function takes an error and the proceeds to wrap it in each of the three error types.

nodes.name: wrapper-short

nodes.text: Another way to do this same wrapping is to use multiline initialization and fill each error type with the next error type, as seen in
. Both of these are valid implementations of the same wrapping.

nodes.name: wrapper-long

nodes.text: , can be used to unwrap an error until it reaches the original error. This will continue to peel the wrapped layers until it, hopefully, reaches the original error.

$ go doc errors.Unwrap

package errors // import "errors"

func Unwrap(err error) error
    Unwrap returns the result of calling the Unwrap method on err, if err's type
    contains an Unwrap method returning error. Otherwise, Unwrap returns nil.

    Unwrap only calls a method of the form "Unwrap() error". In particular
    Unwrap does not unwrap errors returned by Join.

$ go doc errors.Unwrap

package errors // import "errors"

func Unwrap(err error) error
    Unwrap returns the result of calling the Unwrap method on err, if err's type
    contains an Unwrap method returning error. Otherwise, Unwrap returns nil.

    Unwrap only calls a method of the form "Unwrap() error". In particular
    Unwrap does not unwrap errors returned by Join.

To Wrap Or Not to Wrap
We saw that you can use the
verb to wrap an error. This will allow for the
of an error later, either from the caller of your function/method or in a test.
While the normal rule is to always wrap the errors with the
, there are exceptions. If you don't want some internal information or package specific information to not be wrapped, then it is ok to use the
verb to hide any implementation details. Keep in mind, this is normally the exception and not the rule.
If in doubt, it is usually safer to wrap the error so that other code that calls your package can check for specific errors later.
While unwrapping an error allows us to get to the original, underlying error, it does not allow us to get access to any of the other errors that it might have been wrapped with. Consider
. When we unwrap the error returned from the
function we can get access to the original error passed in, but how do we check if the wrapped error has
in its stack and how do we get access to the
, that will help us with these questions.

nodes.name: wrapper-short

nodes.text: A function that nests one error in many errors.
When working with errors, we often don't care about the underlying error, there are times, however, when we do care about the underlying error and we want to get access to it. The
, function is designed to do this. It takes an
and a type to match against. If the error matches the type, it will return the underlying error. If the error does not match the type, it will return

$ go doc errors.As

package errors // import "errors"

func As(err error, target any) bool
    As finds the first error in err's tree that matches target, and if one
    is found, sets target to that error value and returns true. Otherwise,
    it returns false.

    The tree consists of err itself, followed by the errors obtained by
    repeatedly calling Unwrap. When err wraps multiple errors, As examines err
    followed by a depth-first traversal of its children.

    An error matches target if the error's concrete value is assignable to the
    value pointed to by target, or if the error has a method As(interface{})
    bool such that As(target) returns true. In the latter case, the As method is
    responsible for setting target.

    An error type might provide an As method so it can be treated as if it were
    a different error type.

    As panics if target is not a non-nil pointer to either a type that
    implements error, or to any interface type.

$ go doc errors.As

package errors // import "errors"

func As(err error, target any) bool
    As finds the first error in err's tree that matches target, and if one
    is found, sets target to that error value and returns true. Otherwise,
    it returns false.

    The tree consists of err itself, followed by the errors obtained by
    repeatedly calling Unwrap. When err wraps multiple errors, As examines err
    followed by a depth-first traversal of its children.

    An error matches target if the error's concrete value is assignable to the
    value pointed to by target, or if the error has a method As(interface{})
    bool such that As(target) returns true. In the latter case, the As method is
    responsible for setting target.

    An error type might provide an As method so it can be treated as if it were
    a different error type.

    As panics if target is not a non-nil pointer to either a type that
    implements error, or to any interface type.

, is used to check for the type of an error, the
, is used to check if an error in the error chain matches a specific error type. This provides a quick

$ go doc errors.Is

package errors // import "errors"

func Is(err, target error) bool
    Is reports whether any error in err's tree matches target.

    The tree consists of err itself, followed by the errors obtained by
    repeatedly calling Unwrap. When err wraps multiple errors, Is examines err
    followed by a depth-first traversal of its children.

    An error is considered to match a target if it is equal to that target or if
    it implements a method Is(error) bool such that Is(target) returns true.

    An error type might provide an Is method so it can be treated as equivalent
    to an existing error. For example, if MyError defines

        func (m MyError) Is(target error) bool { return target == fs.ErrExist }

    then Is(MyError{}, fs.ErrExist) returns true. See syscall.Errno.Is for an
    example in the standard library. An Is method should only shallowly compare
    err and the target and not call Unwrap on either.

$ go doc errors.Is

package errors // import "errors"

func Is(err, target error) bool
    Is reports whether any error in err's tree matches target.

    The tree consists of err itself, followed by the errors obtained by
    repeatedly calling Unwrap. When err wraps multiple errors, Is examines err
    followed by a depth-first traversal of its children.

    An error is considered to match a target if it is equal to that target or if
    it implements a method Is(error) bool such that Is(target) returns true.

    An error type might provide an Is method so it can be treated as equivalent
    to an existing error. For example, if MyError defines

        func (m MyError) Is(target error) bool { return target == fs.ErrExist }

    then Is(MyError{}, fs.ErrExist) returns true. See syscall.Errno.Is for an
    example in the standard library. An Is method should only shallowly compare
    err and the target and not call Unwrap on either.

Using a stack trace to debug your code can be very helpful at times. A stack trace shows where you are at in the code, and how you got there by printing a list of all calling functions.
package provides a couple of functions that can be use to get, or print, a stack trace. The
, will return a slice of bytes that represent the stack trace.

$ go doc runtime/debug.Stack

package debug // import "runtime/debug"

func Stack() []byte
    Stack returns a formatted stack trace of the goroutine that calls it. It
    calls runtime.Stack with a large enough buffer to capture the entire trace.

$ go doc runtime/debug.Stack

package debug // import "runtime/debug"

func Stack() []byte
    Stack returns a formatted stack trace of the goroutine that calls it. It
    calls runtime.Stack with a large enough buffer to capture the entire trace.
, will print the stack trace to the standard output.
, we print the stack trace of a program to standard output, using

$ go run .

goroutine 1 [running]:
runtime/debug.Stack()
	/usr/local/go/src/runtime/debug/stack.go:24 +0x64
runtime/debug.PrintStack()
	/usr/local/go/src/runtime/debug/stack.go:16 +0x1c
main.Third(...)
	./main.go:18
main.Second(...)
	./main.go:14
main.First(...)
	./main.go:10
main.main()
	./main.go:6 +0x28

$ go run .

	./main.go:6 +0x28
we discussed Go's error handling in depth. We covered error handling, and creation, in our code. We learned how to create custom implementations of
interface. Next, we saw how a panic can crash an application, and we discussed various ways to recover from panics. We saw that we can use
to try and get the original error from a wrapped error. We also saw how to use
to try assert an error has a certain type in its chain, and if so, it binds the error to a variable to be used in the rest of the function. Finally, we saw how to use
to check if an error in the chain is of a certain type.
